awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Multimodal Sensing and Analytics at Scale:  Algorithms and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Finding highly correlated latent factors in multimodal signals and data: Scalable algorithms and applications in sensing, imaging, and language processing

Abstract: Multimodal signals and data arise naturally in many walks of science and engineering, and our digital society presents ever-increasing opportunities to collect and extract useful information from such data. For example, brain magnetic resonance imaging and electro-encephalography are two modes of sensing brain activity that can offer different "views" of the same set of patients (entities). Co-occurrence frequencies of a given set of words in different languages is another example. Crime, poverty, welfare, income, tax, school, unemployment, and other types of social data offer different views of a given set of municipalities. Integrating multiple views to extract meaningful common information is of great interest, and finds a vast amount of timely applications -- in brain imaging, machine translation, landscape change detection in remote sensing, and social science research, to name a few.  However, existing multiview analytics tools -- notably (generalized) canonical correlation analysis [(G)CCA] -- are struggling to keep pace with the size of today's datasets, and the problem is only getting worse. Furthermore, the complex structure and dynamic nature of some of the underlying phenomena are not accounted for in classical GCCA. This project will provide much needed scalable and flexible computational tools for GCCA-based multimodal sensing and analytics, thereby benefiting a large variety of scientific and engineering applications. It will produce a framework allowing for plug-and-play incorporation of application-specific prior information, and distributed implementation. Beyond linear and batch GCCA, nonlinear GCCA and streaming GCCA will be considered. These are appealing and timely for many applications, but associated computational tools are sorely missing.

In terms of theory and methods, many key aspects of GCCA (such as convergence properties, distributed implementation, and streaming variants) are still poorly understood. The research will provide a set of high-performance computational tools that are backed by advanced optimization theory and rigorous convergence guarantees. The research will evolve along the following synergistic thrusts: 1) scalable and stochastic GCCA algorithms; 2) distributed, streaming and nonlinear GCCA algorithms; and 3) validation, using a series of timely and important applications in remote sensing, brain imaging, natural language processing, and sensor array processing. Devising scalable, flexible, streaming, and nonlinear GCCA algorithms is very well-motivated for modern sensing and analytics problems which involve rapidly increasing amounts of data with unknown underlying dynamics. Using GCCA for large-scale dynamic and complex data also poses very challenging and exciting modeling and optimization problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on a type of multiview analysis known as (Generalized) Canonical Correlation Analysis, (G)CCA. CCA is a basic tool in statistics and machine learning, one which has numerous applications in sensing and signal processing, communications, text and language modeling, and many other areas. GCCA is far less studied than CCA.  

 

Intellectual merit: The outcomes of this project are contributions to i) theory, ii) algorithms, and iii) cross-disciplinary applications of (G)CCA. On the theory side, we studied a key theoretical aspect of multiview analysis, namely, the identifiability issue of the shared latent components in (G)CCA models. (G)CCA analysis is usually motivated from a statistical correlation point of view, as the name suggests. It aims to extract highly correlated ("common") latent variables from two (or more) random vectors, or "views". Coming from an algebraic perspective owing to our signal processing pedigree, we considered a (bi-)linear mixture model for multiview data and asked the following question: If different mixtures have some shared components, can CCA provably identify them? This question is very meaningful from an estimation theory point of view, yet it had never before been considered in the CCA literature. Under this generative model, we showed that the range space spanned by the shared components can be recovered by (G)CCA, regardless of how weak energy-wise these shared components are. This is a very powerful result which is bound to find many applications in machine learning and signal processing. Going beyond identifiability, we studied the performance of (G)CCA under non-ideal conditions, including the effect of noise and component leakage, showing that (G)CCA can still be guaranteed to work under such imperfections. On the algorithms side, we devised two new families of effective, scalable and robust algorithms for GCCA and structured GCCA, respectively.  Unlike the plain-vanilla GCCA problem, structured GCCA takes into consideration different structure-promoting regularizations that are often utilized in signal and data analytics, e.g., sparsity, nonnegativity, and smoothness. We proposed an ADMM-like primal-dual update framework with lightweight per-iteration operations, and we provided proof of convergence. Regarding applications, we made strong contributions to two very different application areas: functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data analysis and wireless communications.  fMRI is one of the most important modalities for studying the human brain. It measures brain activity, by detecting local changes in the Blood Oxygen Level Dependent (BOLD) signal in the brain as a function of time. In task-related studies, the goal is to detect which parts of the brain are activated when a specific task is performed. We proposed a new fMRI data generating model which takes into consideration the existence of common task-related and resting-state components. We estimate the common spatial task-related component via a two-stage GCCA approach which is able to separate the task-induced response from the common resting-state components in an unsupervised manner. On the wireless communications front, we proposed two novel applications of GCCA to cell-edge user detection, and dynamic spectrum reuse, respectively. Effective detection on the cell-edge is a notoriously hard problem that persists in 5G systems, and our approach offers a very practical solution using selective base station cooperation. Our work on secondary underlay communication using repetition coding at the transmitter and CCA decoding at the receiver is groundbreaking, in that we know of no other way of effectively communicating in the primary interference-limited regime without coordination and crosstalk channel estimation between the primary and secondary system, especially in time-varying environments where the channels change rapidly over time. Our solution works seamlessly, without coordination, co-training, or supervision; and it was successfully demonstrated in the lab. A patent application is being filed.

 

Broader impacts: Research under this project was inherently multi-disciplinary, bringing together signal processing, linear algebra, optimization, and statistical machine learning tools to bear on problems in fMRI data analysis, wireless communications, radar, and graph mining. The PI has given talks to diverse audiences, including disciplinary colloquia addressing a mix of graduate and undergraduate students, to outreach talks to chemometrics, analytical chemistry, and proteomics audiences, who can benefit from learning about GCCA theory and its application potential. The project partially supported two PhD students and helped the PI attract one undergraduate student who was engaged in research under this grant. One of the PhD students has graduated and joined the US wireless communications industry as an R&D engineer. A patent filing is underway to protect and ultimately license the seamless spectrum underlay invention that was made as part of the work under this grant.
